column6: Leader of the Lewis and Clark Expedition exploring the Louisiana Purchase; Governor of the Louisiana Territory; Secretary to President Thomas Jefferson; Captain in the 1st U.S. Infantry.
column7: Albemarle Co., VA; St. Louis, MO; Philadelphia, PA; Fort Mandan; Fort Clatsop; Chickasaw Bluffs, TN; Charlottesville, VA
column8: William Lewis (Father); Lucy Marks (Mother); Reuben Lewis (Brother); Nicholas Meriwether (Great-great-grandfather); Cousin of James Lewis.

column6: Kentucky pioneer and Indian fighter; built the first brick house west of the Blue Ridge Mountains; served as a Private in John Davidson's company, Kentucky Mounted Infantry in the War of 1812; died at the Battle of the Thames.
column7: Augusta Co., VA; Cedar Creek (near Crab Orchard), KY; Thamesville/Chatham, Ontario, Canada.
column8: Son of Solomon Whitley and Elizabeth Barnett; brother of Sarah Whitley Lewis; father of Elizabeth, Isabella, Levisa, Solomon, William, Andrew, and five others.

column6: Revolutionary War private (3rd Virginia Regiment); Served at Valley Forge; First white settler in Lauderdale County, Alabama; Signer of the Doublehead petition.
column7: Amherst County, VA; Valley Forge; Wilkes/Oglethorpe County, GA; Lawrence Co., TN; Lauderdale Co., AL; Green Hill, AL.
column8: Son of George Gresham and Elizabeth Watts; Father of Philemon, Jarred, and Mollie Leona's grandfather.

column6: Co-leader of the Lewis and Clark Expedition; General in the U.S. Army; Superintendent of Indian Affairs; Founder of Clark's Indian Museum in St. Louis.
column7: St. Louis, MO; Fort Mandan; Fort Clatsop; Fincastle, VA
column8: George Rogers Clark (Brother); Julia Clark (Wife)

column6: Founder of Staunton, Virginia; co-founder of Augusta County; wealthy landowner and magistrate involved in frontier expansion.
column7: Northern Ireland; Shenandoah Valley, Virginia.
column8: Father of General Andrew Lewis and Thomas Lewis.

column6: Brickmason; early American settler in Kentucky; Lieutenant Colonel in the Kentucky Militia (1792); Private in the War of 1812 (7th Regiment, Kentucky Militia).
column7: Emigrated from British Isles; settled in Rock Castle County, KY; possibly died in Burkesville, Cumberland County, KY.
column8: Husband of Sarah Whitley; brother-in-law to William Whitley; father of eight children including Samuel, Ruth, and Benjamin.

column6: President Emeritus and Distinguished Professor of Humanities at Bethany College; Author; Lecturer in Political Economy and Gerontology.
column7: Covina, CA; Fort Worth, TX; Seattle, WA; Detroit, MI; Bethany, WV; Advance, NC.
column8: Son of George Edward Gresham and Mary Elizabeth Epler Gresham; Father to Glen and Nancy.

column6: Historian and researcher; author of numerous papers on Meriwether Lewis and early St. Louis; M.A. in History from the University of Texas.
column7: St. Louis, MO; Austin, TX; Palm Springs, CA
column8: Jefferson L. Miller (Son); Philip Miller (Son); C. Carter Lewis (Brother); Rhea Vollmar (Sister)

column6: Served in the Continental Army during the American Revolution under General Francis Marion.
column7: Orange County, NC; Sumner County, TN; Smith County, TN.
column8: Father of Harris Jr., Peter, Davis, Joseph, and Nelly.

column6: Served in the War of 1812 in Captain James Tubbs' Company, 2nd Regiment, Tenn. Militia.
column7: Virginia/South Carolina; Smith County, TN; Pope County, IL.
column8: Son of Harris Grisham, Sr.; Father of 13 children including William, Polly, and Wiley M.

column6: Immigrant to America; Planter; Signed Northumberland Oath of Allegiance to the Commonwealth of England (1652).
column7: England; Virginia; Isle of Kent, Maryland; Northumberland County, VA.
column8: Son of Sir Edward Gresham and Mary Clarke; Brother to Edward; Father to John, Mary, Martha, Katherine, and Justinian.

column6: Immigrant to Virginia (1650); held extensive land patents in New Kent (King and Queen) County; Headright Patent recipient.
column7: England to New Kent County, VA (Axolls Swamp).
column8: Assumed father of Thomas, John, Edward, and George Gresham of the 1704 Quit Rent Rolls.

column3: New Haven, New Haven Co., CT
column6: Loyalist during the American Revolution; Served in Jackson's Creek Militia and Little River Militia (Loyalist units).

column3: New Haven, New Haven Co., CT
column6: Farmer; Subject of genealogical research focusing on Loyalist and Methodist family background; participant in court case Jabez Perkins vs. Elisha Blevins.

column6: Master gunsmith known for producing the 'Kentucky Rifle' near Green Hill; Owner of 300 acres of land.
column7: Tennessee; Green Hill, AL; St. Joseph, Lawrence County, TN.
column8: Son of John and Margaret Emory McDonald; Brother of Joseph Emory and John Scruggs McDonald.

column6: Teacher, blacksmith, gunsmith, silversmith, and wagon-maker; Served as a Justice of the Peace for twelve years; Private in Lauderdale County Militia.
column7: Tennessee; Green Hill, AL.
column8: Son of John and Margaret Emory McDonald; Father of Sarah Margaret, Stephen Emory, and Allen Carroll.

column6: Civil War Veteran (Union Army, Company C, 1st Regiment of Kentucky Light Artillery); Blacksmith and miller.
column7: Lauderdale County, AL; Kentucky; Florence, AL.
column8: Youngest son of John and Margaret Emory McDonald; Father of John Scruggs Jr., James Francis, Jahue Scruggs, and Jesse William.

column6: Inventor of the automatic coupler for railway cars; Part-time Baptist minister.
column7: Pope County, IL; Washington, D.C.
column8: Son of Davis and Sarah (Sally) Grisham.

column6: Early American settler; taught Presbyterian catechism at Whitley's Station.

column8: Father of John (b. ca. 1744) and James (b. ca. 1746).
